g.title: Rectangle
g.text: Observer (=Dependents, Publish-Subscribe)Define a one-to-many dependency between objects so that when one object changes state, all its dependents are notified and updated automatically.

g.title: Rectangle.119
g.desc: The exact (number of) objects that need to be notified, when ...
g.text: The exact (number of) objects that need to be notified, when a given object changes state, is priorly unknown

g.title: Folded Corner.196
g.desc: The Observer ensures stability of the code base by adhering t...

g.text: The Observer ensures stability of the code base by adhering to the Open Closed Principle. This advantage is gained via abstractions. Abstractions however, also introduce an additional form of indirection. Indirection has negative impact on the navigability and debuggability of the code. The most extreme case, of not applying the Observer pattern, would be that the Subject depends on a concrete Observer. This could be ‘ok’ in certain situations. Another case could be that the Subject depends on an abstract Observer. This already provides the flexibility of the concrete Observer to change and still re-use the Subject. However, if more Observers need to listen to the same Subject, then the Subject needs to change. The Observer pattern should be applied in case it is priorly known that more Observers will listen to the same Subject, only the exact amount of Observers is not. However, if this requirement is not true (and also the runtime flexibility to attach/detach is not required), then the Observer pattern is ‘overdone’. Why not always apply the Observer pattern when the Subject already depends on an abstract Observer? Because the Attach and Detach functionality (=collection management) of the Observer pattern add additional maintenance and complexity to the Subject!

g.title: Folded Corner.235
g.desc: The Observer design pattern provides a subscription-model. Su...

g.text: The Observer design pattern provides a subscription-model. Such a model consist of a publisher, that broadcasts information, and a subscriber, that listens to this broadcast. The publisher is called the Subject and the subscriber is called the Observer. The Subject changes state because of an external stimulus. It then notifies its Observers, whom in return request more detailed information from the Subject. The Subject provides functionality to attach and detach abstract Observers. This abstraction enables the possibility to attach new concrete observers with relative ease (as long as they are following the Observer abstraction). As a result, the Subject does not require any change to support a new kind or more Observers. This enables in unfamiliarity with the exact dependencies during development of the Subject, which ensures independent development in different layers of the software architecture.

g.title: Folded Corner.258
g.desc: The Observer design pattern compliments the Open Closed princ...

g.text: The Observer design pattern compliments the Open Closed principle by allowing new Observers to attach to existing Subjects without changing the Subject. The Open Closed Principle is supported by the Dependency inversion principle; both Subjects and Observers dependent on abstractions. This all has positive impact on the stability, reusability and testability of the code. Stability, because the existing Subjects and Observers do not require change in production or test code in case of extension. A new Observer can be introduced and attached to an existing Subject. This is possible due to the attach and detach functionality of the Subject being dependent on an abstract Observer. The Observer is also dependent on an abstract Subject. This enables the possibility to change the Subject of an existing Observer without directly changing the Observer. Reusability, both Observer and Subject are dependent on an abstraction making them reusable with different concrete Observers and Subject. Testability, the inverted dependency, Observers and Subjects being dependent on abstractions, allows mock-ability and thus improves testability of the code.

g.title: Rectangle.261
g.desc: A runtime solution to subscribe and unsubscribe objects listi...
g.text: A runtime solution to subscribe and unsubscribe objects listing to other objects

g.title: Folded Corner.265
g.desc: The Observer design pattern enables the possibility to Attach...

g.text: The Observer design pattern enables the possibility to Attach and Detach objects to other objects during runtime. The Subject interface has Attach and Detach functionality that enables Observer(s) to couple and decouple. A requirement might be that Observers should listen only for a limited amount of time or only in specific cases to certain Subjects. Dynamically controlling the dependency model in your code enables such behavior.
